55 // IMGUI_API is used for core imgui functions, IMGUI_IMPL_API is used for the default bindings files (imgui_impl_xxx.h)
56 // Using dear imgui via a shared library is not recommended, because of function call overhead and because we don't guarantee backward nor forward ABI compatibility.

67 #define IM_ASSERT(_EXPR) assert(_EXPR) // You can override the default assert handler by editing imconfig.h
68 #endif
69 #if defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__)
70 #define IM_FMTARGS(FMT) __attribute__((format(printf, FMT, FMT+1))) // To apply printf-style warnings to our functions.
71 #define IM_FMTLIST(FMT) __attribute__((format(printf, FMT, 0)))
72 #else
73 #define IM_FMTARGS(FMT)
74 #define IM_FMTLIST(FMT)
75 #endif
76 #define IM_ARRAYSIZE(_ARR) ((int)(sizeof(_ARR) / sizeof(*_ARR))) // Size of a static C-style array. Don't use on pointers!
77 #define IM_UNUSED(_VAR) ((void)_VAR) // Used to silence "unused variable warnings". Often useful as asserts may be stripped out from final builds.
78 #if (__cplusplus >= 201100)
79 #define IM_OFFSETOF(_TYPE,_MEMBER) offsetof(_TYPE, _MEMBER) // Offset of _MEMBER within _TYPE. Standardized as offsetof() in C++11
80 #else
81 #define IM_OFFSETOF(_TYPE,_MEMBER) ((size_t)&(((_TYPE*)0)->_MEMBER)) // Offset of _MEMBER within _TYPE. Old style macro.
82 #endif
83 #define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX 0xFFFF // Last Unicode code point supported by this build.
84 #define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_INVALID 0xFFFD // Standard invalid Unicode code point.

103 struct ImDrawChannel; // Temporary storage to output draw commands out of order, used by ImDrawListSplitter and ImDrawList::ChannelsSplit()
104 struct ImDrawCmd; // A single draw command within a parent ImDrawList (generally maps to 1 GPU draw call, unless it is a callback)
105 struct ImDrawData; // All draw command lists required to render the frame + pos/size coordinates to use for the projection matrix.
106 struct ImDrawList; // A single draw command list (generally one per window, conceptually you may see this as a dynamic "mesh" builder)
107 struct ImDrawListSharedData; // Data shared among multiple draw lists (typically owned by parent ImGui context, but you may create one yourself)
108 struct ImDrawListSplitter; // Helper to split a draw list into different layers which can be drawn into out of order, then flattened back.
109 struct ImDrawVert; // A single vertex (pos + uv + col = 20 bytes by default. Override layout with IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT)
110 struct ImFont; // Runtime data for a single font within a parent ImFontAtlas
111 struct ImFontAtlas; // Runtime data for multiple fonts, bake multiple fonts into a single texture, TTF/OTF font loader
112 struct ImFontConfig; // Configuration data when adding a font or merging fonts
113 struct ImFontGlyph; // A single font glyph (code point + coordinates within in ImFontAtlas + offset)
114 struct ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder; // Helper to build glyph ranges from text/string data
115 struct ImColor; // Helper functions to create a color that can be converted to either u32 or float4 (*OBSOLETE* please avoid using)
116 struct ImGuiContext; // Dear ImGui context (opaque structure, unless including imgui_internal.h)
117 struct ImGuiIO; // Main configuration and I/O between your application and ImGui
118 struct ImGuiInputTextCallbackData; // Shared state of InputText() when using custom ImGuiInputTextCallback (rare/advanced use)
119 struct ImGuiListClipper; // Helper to manually clip large list of items
120 struct ImGuiOnceUponAFrame; // Helper for running a block of code not more than once a frame, used by IMGUI_ONCE_UPON_A_FRAME macro
121 struct ImGuiPayload; // User data payload for drag and drop operations
122 struct ImGuiSizeCallbackData; // Callback data when using SetNextWindowSizeConstraints() (rare/advanced use)
123 struct ImGuiStorage; // Helper for key->value storage
124 struct ImGuiStyle; // Runtime data for styling/colors
125 struct ImGuiTextBuffer; // Helper to hold and append into a text buffer (~string builder)
126 struct ImGuiTextFilter; // Helper to parse and apply text filters (e.g. "aaaaa[,bbbb][,ccccc]")

128 // Typedefs and Enums/Flags (declared as int for compatibility with old C++, to allow using as flags and to not pollute the top of this file)

142 typedef int ImGuiStyleVar; // -> enum ImGuiStyleVar_ // Enum: A variable identifier for styling
143 typedef int ImDrawCornerFlags; // -> enum ImDrawCornerFlags_ // Flags: for ImDrawList::AddRect(), AddRectFilled() etc.
144 typedef int ImDrawListFlags; // -> enum ImDrawListFlags_ // Flags: for ImDrawList

146 typedef int ImGuiBackendFlags; // -> enum ImGuiBackendFlags_ // Flags: for io.BackendFlags

150 typedef int ImGuiDragDropFlags; // -> enum ImGuiDragDropFlags_ // Flags: for BeginDragDropSource(), AcceptDragDropPayload()
151 typedef int ImGuiFocusedFlags; // -> enum ImGuiFocusedFlags_ // Flags: for IsWindowFocused()
152 typedef int ImGuiHoveredFlags; // -> enum ImGuiHoveredFlags_ // Flags: for IsItemHovered(), IsWindowHovered() etc.
153 typedef int ImGuiInputTextFlags; // -> enum ImGuiInputTextFlags_ // Flags: for InputText(), InputTextMultiline()
154 typedef int ImGuiSelectableFlags; // -> enum ImGuiSelectableFlags_ // Flags: for Selectable()
155 typedef int ImGuiTabBarFlags; // -> enum ImGuiTabBarFlags_ // Flags: for BeginTabBar()

157 typedef int ImGuiTreeNodeFlags; // -> enum ImGuiTreeNodeFlags_ // Flags: for TreeNode(), TreeNodeEx(), CollapsingHeader()

162 // Scalar data types
163 typedef signed char ImS8; // 8-bit signed integer
164 typedef unsigned char ImU8; // 8-bit unsigned integer
165 typedef signed short ImS16; // 16-bit signed integer
166 typedef unsigned short ImU16; // 16-bit unsigned integer
167 typedef signed int ImS32; // 32-bit signed integer == int
168 typedef unsigned int ImU32; // 32-bit unsigned integer (often used to store packed colors)
169 #if defined(_MSC_VER) && !defined(__clang__)
170 typedef signed __int64 ImS64; // 64-bit signed integer (pre and post C++11 with Visual Studio)
171 typedef unsigned __int64 ImU64; // 64-bit unsigned integer (pre and post C++11 with Visual Studio)
172 #elif (defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__)) && (__cplusplus < 201100)
173 #include <stdint.h>
174 typedef int64_t ImS64; // 64-bit signed integer (pre C++11)
175 typedef uint64_t ImU64; // 64-bit unsigned integer (pre C++11)
176 #else
177 typedef signed long long ImS64; // 64-bit signed integer (post C++11)
178 typedef unsigned long long ImU64; // 64-bit unsigned integer (post C++11)
179 #endif

181 // 2D vector (often used to store positions, sizes, etc.)
182 struct ImVec2
183 {
184  float x, y;
185  ImVec2() { x = y = 0.0f; }
186  ImVec2(float _x, float _y) { x = _x; y = _y; }
187  float operator[] (size_t idx) const { IM_ASSERT(idx <= 1); return (&x)[idx]; } // We very rarely use this [] operator, the assert overhead is fine.
188  float& operator[] (size_t idx) { IM_ASSERT(idx <= 1); return (&x)[idx]; } // We very rarely use this [] operator, the assert overhead is fine.
189 #ifdef IM_VEC2_CLASS_EXTRA
190  IM_VEC2_CLASS_EXTRA // Define additional constructors and implicit cast operators in imconfig.h to convert back and forth between your math types and ImVec2.
191 #endif
192 };
193 
194 // 4D vector (often used to store floating-point colors)
195 struct ImVec4
196 {
197  float x, y, z, w;
198  ImVec4() { x = y = z = w = 0.0f; }
199  ImVec4(float _x, float _y, float _z, float _w) { x = _x; y = _y; z = _z; w = _w; }
200 #ifdef IM_VEC4_CLASS_EXTRA
201  IM_VEC4_CLASS_EXTRA // Define additional constructors and implicit cast operators in imconfig.h to convert back and forth between your math types and ImVec4.
202 #endif
203 };

212  // Context creation and access
213  // Each context create its own ImFontAtlas by default. You may instance one yourself and pass it to CreateContext() to share a font atlas between imgui contexts.
214  // None of those functions is reliant on the current context.
215  IMGUI_API ImGuiContext* CreateContext(ImFontAtlas* shared_font_atlas = NULL);
216  IMGUI_API void DestroyContext(ImGuiContext* ctx = NULL); // NULL = destroy current context
217  IMGUI_API ImGuiContext* GetCurrentContext();
218  IMGUI_API void SetCurrentContext(ImGuiContext* ctx);
219  IMGUI_API bool DebugCheckVersionAndDataLayout(const char* version_str, size_t sz_io, size_t sz_style, size_t sz_vec2, size_t sz_vec4, size_t sz_drawvert, size_t sz_drawidx);

221  // Main
222  IMGUI_API ImGuiIO& GetIO(); // access the IO structure (mouse/keyboard/gamepad inputs, time, various configuration options/flags)
223  IMGUI_API ImGuiStyle& GetStyle(); // access the Style structure (colors, sizes). Always use PushStyleCol(), PushStyleVar() to modify style mid-frame.
224  IMGUI_API void NewFrame(); // start a new Dear ImGui frame, you can submit any command from this point until Render()/EndFrame().
225  IMGUI_API void EndFrame(); // ends the Dear ImGui frame. automatically called by Render(), you likely don't need to call that yourself directly. If you don't need to render data (skipping rendering) you may call EndFrame() but you'll have wasted CPU already! If you don't need to render, better to not create any imgui windows and not call NewFrame() at all!
226  IMGUI_API void Render(); // ends the Dear ImGui frame, finalize the draw data. You can get call GetDrawData() to obtain it and run your rendering function. (Obsolete: this used to call io.RenderDrawListsFn(). Nowadays, we allow and prefer calling your render function yourself.)
227  IMGUI_API ImDrawData* GetDrawData(); // valid after Render() and until the next call to NewFrame(). this is what you have to render.

244  // Windows
245  // - Begin() = push window to the stack and start appending to it. End() = pop window from the stack.
246  // - You may append multiple times to the same window during the same frame.
247  // - Passing 'bool* p_open != NULL' shows a window-closing widget in the upper-right corner of the window,
248  // which clicking will set the boolean to false when clicked.
249  // - Begin() return false to indicate the window is collapsed or fully clipped, so you may early out and omit submitting
250  // anything to the window. Always call a matching End() for each Begin() call, regardless of its return value!
251  // [Important: due to legacy reason, this is inconsistent with most other functions such as BeginMenu/EndMenu,
252  // BeginPopup/EndPopup, etc. where the EndXXX call should only be called if the corresponding BeginXXX function
253  // returned true. Begin and BeginChild are the only odd ones out. Will be fixed in a future update.]
254  // - Note that the bottom of window stack always contains a window called "Debug".
255  IMGUI_API bool Begin(const char* name, bool* p_open = NULL, ImGuiWindowFlags flags = 0);
256  IMGUI_API void End();
257 
258  // Child Windows
259  // - Use child windows to begin into a self-contained independent scrolling/clipping regions within a host window. Child windows can embed their own child.
260  // - For each independent axis of 'size': ==0.0f: use remaining host window size / >0.0f: fixed size / <0.0f: use remaining window size minus abs(size) / Each axis can use a different mode, e.g. ImVec2(0,400).
261  // - BeginChild() returns false to indicate the window is collapsed or fully clipped, so you may early out and omit submitting anything to the window.
262  // Always call a matching EndChild() for each BeginChild() call, regardless of its return value [as with Begin: this is due to legacy reason and inconsistent with most BeginXXX functions apart from the regular Begin() which behaves like BeginChild().]
263  IMGUI_API bool BeginChild(const char* str_id, const ImVec2& size = ImVec2(0,0), bool border = false, ImGuiWindowFlags flags = 0);
264  IMGUI_API bool BeginChild(ImGuiID id, const ImVec2& size = ImVec2(0,0), bool border = false, ImGuiWindowFlags flags = 0);
265  IMGUI_API void EndChild();

NB: If you are trying to check whether your mouse should be dispatched to imgui or to your app, you should use the 'io.WantCaptureMouse' boolean for that! Please read the FAQ!

279  // Prefer using SetNextXXX functions (before Begin) rather that SetXXX functions (after Begin).
280  IMGUI_API void SetNextWindowPos(const ImVec2& pos, ImGuiCond cond = 0, const ImVec2& pivot = ImVec2(0,0)); // set next window position. call before Begin(). use pivot=(0.5f,0.5f) to center on given point, etc.
281  IMGUI_API void SetNextWindowSize(const ImVec2& size, ImGuiCond cond = 0); // set next window size. set axis to 0.0f to force an auto-fit on this axis. call before Begin()
282  IMGUI_API void SetNextWindowSizeConstraints(const ImVec2& size_min, const ImVec2& size_max, ImGuiSizeCallback custom_callback = NULL, void* custom_callback_data = NULL); // set next window size limits. use -1,-1 on either X/Y axis to preserve the current size. Sizes will be rounded down. Use callback to apply non-trivial programmatic constraints.
283  IMGUI_API void SetNextWindowContentSize(const ImVec2& size); // set next window content size (~ scrollable client area, which enforce the range of scrollbars). Not including window decorations (title bar, menu bar, etc.) nor WindowPadding. set an axis to 0.0f to leave it automatic. call before Begin()
284  IMGUI_API void SetNextWindowCollapsed(bool collapsed, ImGuiCond cond = 0); // set next window collapsed state. call before Begin()

287  IMGUI_API void SetWindowPos(const ImVec2& pos, ImGuiCond cond = 0); // (not recommended) set current window position - call within Begin()/End(). prefer using SetNextWindowPos(), as this may incur tearing and side-effects.
288  IMGUI_API void SetWindowSize(const ImVec2& size, ImGuiCond cond = 0); // (not recommended) set current window size - call within Begin()/End(). set to ImVec2(0,0) to force an auto-fit. prefer using SetNextWindowSize(), as this may incur tearing and minor side-effects.

291  IMGUI_API void SetWindowFontScale(float scale); // set font scale. Adjust IO.FontGlobalScale if you want to scale all windows. This is an old API! For correct scaling, prefer to reload font + rebuild ImFontAtlas + call style.ScaleAllSizes().

374  // ID stack/scopes
375  // - Read the FAQ for more details about how ID are handled in dear imgui. If you are creating widgets in a loop you most
376  // likely want to push a unique identifier (e.g. object pointer, loop index) to uniquely differentiate them.
377  // - The resulting ID are hashes of the entire stack.
378  // - You can also use the "Label##foobar" syntax within widget label to distinguish them from each others.
379  // - In this header file we use the "label"/"name" terminology to denote a string that will be displayed and used as an ID,
380  // whereas "str_id" denote a string that is only used as an ID and not normally displayed.
381  IMGUI_API void PushID(const char* str_id); // push string into the ID stack (will hash string).
382  IMGUI_API void PushID(const char* str_id_begin, const char* str_id_end); // push string into the ID stack (will hash string).
383  IMGUI_API void PushID(const void* ptr_id); // push pointer into the ID stack (will hash pointer).
384  IMGUI_API void PushID(int int_id); // push integer into the ID stack (will hash integer).
385  IMGUI_API void PopID(); // pop from the ID stack.
386  IMGUI_API ImGuiID GetID(const char* str_id); // calculate unique ID (hash of whole ID stack + given parameter). e.g. if you want to query into ImGuiStorage yourself
387  IMGUI_API ImGuiID GetID(const char* str_id_begin, const char* str_id_end);
388  IMGUI_API ImGuiID GetID(const void* ptr_id);

431  // - CTRL+Click on any drag box to turn them into an input box. Manually input values aren't clamped and can go off-bounds.
432  // - For all the Float2/Float3/Float4/Int2/Int3/Int4 versions of every functions, note that a 'float v[X]' function argument is the same as 'float* v', the array syntax is just a way to document the number of elements that are expected to be accessible. You can pass address of your first element out of a contiguous set, e.g. &myvector.x
433  // - Adjust format string to decorate the value with a prefix, a suffix, or adapt the editing and display precision e.g. "%.3f" -> 1.234; "%5.2f secs" -> 01.23 secs; "Biscuit: %.0f" -> Biscuit: 1; etc.
434  // - Speed are per-pixel of mouse movement (v_speed=0.2f: mouse needs to move by 5 pixels to increase value by 1). For gamepad/keyboard navigation, minimum speed is Max(v_speed, minimum_step_at_given_precision).
435  // - Use v_min < v_max to clamp edits to given limits. Note that CTRL+Click manual input can override those limits.
436  // - Use v_min > v_max to lock edits.

562  // Popups, Modals
563  // The properties of popups windows are:
564  // - They block normal mouse hovering detection outside them. (*)
565  // - Unless modal, they can be closed by clicking anywhere outside them, or by pressing ESCAPE.
566  // - Their visibility state (~bool) is held internally by imgui instead of being held by the programmer as we are used to with regular Begin() calls.
567  // User can manipulate the visibility state by calling OpenPopup().
568  // (*) You can use IsItemHovered(ImGuiHoveredFlags_AllowWhenBlockedByPopup) to bypass it and detect hovering even when normally blocked by a popup.
569  // Those three properties are connected. The library needs to hold their visibility state because it can close popups at any time.
570  IMGUI_API void OpenPopup(const char* str_id); // call to mark popup as open (don't call every frame!). popups are closed when user click outside, or if CloseCurrentPopup() is called within a BeginPopup()/EndPopup() block. By default, Selectable()/MenuItem() are calling CloseCurrentPopup(). Popup identifiers are relative to the current ID-stack (so OpenPopup and BeginPopup needs to be at the same level).
571  IMGUI_API bool BeginPopup(const char* str_id, ImGuiWindowFlags flags = 0); // return true if the popup is open, and you can start outputting to it. only call EndPopup() if BeginPopup() returns true!
572  IMGUI_API bool BeginPopupContextItem(const char* str_id = NULL, int mouse_button = 1); // helper to open and begin popup when clicked on last item. if you can pass a NULL str_id only if the previous item had an id. If you want to use that on a non-interactive item such as Text() you need to pass in an explicit ID here. read comments in .cpp!
573  IMGUI_API bool BeginPopupContextWindow(const char* str_id = NULL, int mouse_button = 1, bool also_over_items = true); // helper to open and begin popup when clicked on current window.
574  IMGUI_API bool BeginPopupContextVoid(const char* str_id = NULL, int mouse_button = 1); // helper to open and begin popup when clicked in void (where there are no imgui windows).
575  IMGUI_API bool BeginPopupModal(const char* name, bool* p_open = NULL, ImGuiWindowFlags flags = 0); // modal dialog (regular window with title bar, block interactions behind the modal window, can't close the modal window by clicking outside)
576  IMGUI_API void EndPopup(); // only call EndPopup() if BeginPopupXXX() returns true!
577  IMGUI_API bool OpenPopupOnItemClick(const char* str_id = NULL, int mouse_button = 1); // helper to open popup when clicked on last item (note: actually triggers on the mouse _released_ event to be consistent with popup behaviors). return true when just opened.
578  IMGUI_API bool IsPopupOpen(const char* str_id); // return true if the popup is open at the current begin-ed level of the popup stack.
579  IMGUI_API void CloseCurrentPopup(); // close the popup we have begin-ed into. clicking on a MenuItem or Selectable automatically close the current popup.

720 // Flags for ImGui::Begin()
721 enum ImGuiWindowFlags_
722 {
723  ImGuiWindowFlags_None = 0,
724  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoTitleBar = 1 << 0, // Disable title-bar
725  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoResize = 1 << 1, // Disable user resizing with the lower-right grip
726  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoMove = 1 << 2, // Disable user moving the window
727  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoScrollbar = 1 << 3, // Disable scrollbars (window can still scroll with mouse or programmatically)
728  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoScrollWithMouse = 1 << 4, // Disable user vertically scrolling with mouse wheel. On child window, mouse wheel will be forwarded to the parent unless NoScrollbar is also set.
729  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoCollapse = 1 << 5, // Disable user collapsing window by double-clicking on it
730  ImGuiWindowFlags_AlwaysAutoResize = 1 << 6, // Resize every window to its content every frame
731  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoBackground = 1 << 7, // Disable drawing background color (WindowBg, etc.) and outside border. Similar as using SetNextWindowBgAlpha(0.0f).
732  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoSavedSettings = 1 << 8, // Never load/save settings in .ini file
733  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoMouseInputs = 1 << 9, // Disable catching mouse, hovering test with pass through.
734  ImGuiWindowFlags_MenuBar = 1 << 10, // Has a menu-bar
735  ImGuiWindowFlags_HorizontalScrollbar = 1 << 11, // Allow horizontal scrollbar to appear (off by default). You may use SetNextWindowContentSize(ImVec2(width,0.0f)); prior to calling Begin() to specify width. Read code in imgui_demo in the "Horizontal Scrolling" section.
736  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoFocusOnAppearing = 1 << 12, // Disable taking focus when transitioning from hidden to visible state
737  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoBringToFrontOnFocus = 1 << 13, // Disable bringing window to front when taking focus (e.g. clicking on it or programmatically giving it focus)
738  ImGuiWindowFlags_AlwaysVerticalScrollbar= 1 << 14, // Always show vertical scrollbar (even if ContentSize.y < Size.y)
739  ImGuiWindowFlags_AlwaysHorizontalScrollbar=1<< 15, // Always show horizontal scrollbar (even if ContentSize.x < Size.x)
740  ImGuiWindowFlags_AlwaysUseWindowPadding = 1 << 16, // Ensure child windows without border uses style.WindowPadding (ignored by default for non-bordered child windows, because more convenient)
741  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavInputs = 1 << 18, // No gamepad/keyboard navigation within the window
742  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavFocus = 1 << 19, // No focusing toward this window with gamepad/keyboard navigation (e.g. skipped by CTRL+TAB)
743  ImGuiWindowFlags_UnsavedDocument = 1 << 20, // Append '*' to title without affecting the ID, as a convenience to avoid using the ### operator. When used in a tab/docking context, tab is selected on closure and closure is deferred by one frame to allow code to cancel the closure (with a confirmation popup, etc.) without flicker.
744  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNav = ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavInputs | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavFocus,
745  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoDecoration = ImGuiWindowFlags_NoTitleBar | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoResize | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoScrollbar | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoCollapse,
746  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoInputs = ImGuiWindowFlags_NoMouseInputs | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavInputs | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavFocus,
747 
748  // [Internal]
749  ImGuiWindowFlags_NavFlattened = 1 << 23, // [BETA] Allow gamepad/keyboard navigation to cross over parent border to this child (only use on child that have no scrolling!)
750  ImGuiWindowFlags_ChildWindow = 1 << 24, // Don't use! For internal use by BeginChild()
751  ImGuiWindowFlags_Tooltip = 1 << 25, // Don't use! For internal use by BeginTooltip()
752  ImGuiWindowFlags_Popup = 1 << 26, // Don't use! For internal use by BeginPopup()
753  ImGuiWindowFlags_Modal = 1 << 27, // Don't use! For internal use by BeginPopupModal()
754  ImGuiWindowFlags_ChildMenu = 1 << 28 // Don't use! For internal use by BeginMenu()
755 
756  // [Obsolete]
757  //ImGuiWindowFlags_ShowBorders = 1 << 7, // --> Set style.FrameBorderSize=1.0f / style.WindowBorderSize=1.0f to enable borders around windows and items
758  //ImGuiWindowFlags_ResizeFromAnySide = 1 << 17, // --> Set io.ConfigWindowsResizeFromEdges and make sure mouse cursors are supported by back-end (io.BackendFlags & ImGuiBackendFlags_HasMouseCursors)
759 };
760 
761 // Flags for ImGui::InputText()
762 enum ImGuiInputTextFlags_
763 {
764  ImGuiInputTextFlags_None = 0,
765  ImGuiInputTextFlags_CharsDecimal = 1 << 0, // Allow 0123456789.+-*/
766  ImGuiInputTextFlags_CharsHexadecimal = 1 << 1, // Allow 0123456789ABCDEFabcdef
767  ImGuiInputTextFlags_CharsUppercase = 1 << 2, // Turn a..z into A..Z
768  ImGuiInputTextFlags_CharsNoBlank = 1 << 3, // Filter out spaces, tabs
769  ImGuiInputTextFlags_AutoSelectAll = 1 << 4, // Select entire text when first taking mouse focus
770  ImGuiInputTextFlags_EnterReturnsTrue = 1 << 5, // Return 'true' when Enter is pressed (as opposed to every time the value was modified). Consider looking at the IsItemDeactivatedAfterEdit() function.

972 // Gamepad/Keyboard directional navigation
973 // Keyboard: Set io.ConfigFlags |= ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableKeyboard to enable. NewFrame() will automatically fill io.NavInputs[] based on your io.KeysDown[] + io.KeyMap[] arrays.
974 // Gamepad: Set io.ConfigFlags |= ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableGamepad to enable. Back-end: set ImGuiBackendFlags_HasGamepad and fill the io.NavInputs[] fields before calling NewFrame(). Note that io.NavInputs[] is cleared by EndFrame().
975 // Read instructions in imgui.cpp for more details. Download PNG/PSD at http://goo.gl/9LgVZW.
976 enum ImGuiNavInput_
977 {
978  // Gamepad Mapping
979  ImGuiNavInput_Activate, // activate / open / toggle / tweak value // e.g. Cross (PS4), A (Xbox), A (Switch), Space (Keyboard)
980  ImGuiNavInput_Cancel, // cancel / close / exit // e.g. Circle (PS4), B (Xbox), B (Switch), Escape (Keyboard)
981  ImGuiNavInput_Input, // text input / on-screen keyboard // e.g. Triang.(PS4), Y (Xbox), X (Switch), Return (Keyboard)
982  ImGuiNavInput_Menu, // tap: toggle menu / hold: focus, move, resize // e.g. Square (PS4), X (Xbox), Y (Switch), Alt (Keyboard)
983  ImGuiNavInput_DpadLeft, // move / tweak / resize window (w/ PadMenu) // e.g. D-pad Left/Right/Up/Down (Gamepads), Arrow keys (Keyboard)
984  ImGuiNavInput_DpadRight, //
985  ImGuiNavInput_DpadUp, //
986  ImGuiNavInput_DpadDown, //
987  ImGuiNavInput_LStickLeft, // scroll / move window (w/ PadMenu) // e.g. Left Analog Stick Left/Right/Up/Down
988  ImGuiNavInput_LStickRight, //
989  ImGuiNavInput_LStickUp, //
990  ImGuiNavInput_LStickDown, //
991  ImGuiNavInput_FocusPrev, // next window (w/ PadMenu) // e.g. L1 or L2 (PS4), LB or LT (Xbox), L or ZL (Switch)
992  ImGuiNavInput_FocusNext, // prev window (w/ PadMenu) // e.g. R1 or R2 (PS4), RB or RT (Xbox), R or ZL (Switch)
993  ImGuiNavInput_TweakSlow, // slower tweaks // e.g. L1 or L2 (PS4), LB or LT (Xbox), L or ZL (Switch)
994  ImGuiNavInput_TweakFast, // faster tweaks // e.g. R1 or R2 (PS4), RB or RT (Xbox), R or ZL (Switch)
995 
996  // [Internal] Don't use directly! This is used internally to differentiate keyboard from gamepad inputs for behaviors that require to differentiate them.
997  // Keyboard behavior that have no corresponding gamepad mapping (e.g. CTRL+TAB) will be directly reading from io.KeysDown[] instead of io.NavInputs[].
998  ImGuiNavInput_KeyMenu_, // toggle menu // = io.KeyAlt
999  ImGuiNavInput_KeyLeft_, // move left // = Arrow keys
1000  ImGuiNavInput_KeyRight_, // move right
1001  ImGuiNavInput_KeyUp_, // move up
1002  ImGuiNavInput_KeyDown_, // move down
1003  ImGuiNavInput_COUNT,
1004  ImGuiNavInput_InternalStart_ = ImGuiNavInput_KeyMenu_
1005 };

1007 // Configuration flags stored in io.ConfigFlags. Set by user/application.
1008 enum ImGuiConfigFlags_
1009 {
1010  ImGuiConfigFlags_None = 0,
1011  ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableKeyboard = 1 << 0, // Master keyboard navigation enable flag. NewFrame() will automatically fill io.NavInputs[] based on io.KeysDown[].
1012  ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableGamepad = 1 << 1, // Master gamepad navigation enable flag. This is mostly to instruct your imgui back-end to fill io.NavInputs[]. Back-end also needs to set ImGuiBackendFlags_HasGamepad.
1013  ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableSetMousePos = 1 << 2, // Instruct navigation to move the mouse cursor. May be useful on TV/console systems where moving a virtual mouse is awkward. Will update io.MousePos and set io.WantSetMousePos=true. If enabled you MUST honor io.WantSetMousePos requests in your binding, otherwise ImGui will react as if the mouse is jumping around back and forth.
1014  ImGuiConfigFlags_NavNoCaptureKeyboard = 1 << 3, // Instruct navigation to not set the io.WantCaptureKeyboard flag when io.NavActive is set.
1015  ImGuiConfigFlags_NoMouse = 1 << 4, // Instruct imgui to clear mouse position/buttons in NewFrame(). This allows ignoring the mouse information set by the back-end.
1016  ImGuiConfigFlags_NoMouseCursorChange = 1 << 5, // Instruct back-end to not alter mouse cursor shape and visibility. Use if the back-end cursor changes are interfering with yours and you don't want to use SetMouseCursor() to change mouse cursor. You may want to honor requests from imgui by reading GetMouseCursor() yourself instead.
1017 
1018  // User storage (to allow your back-end/engine to communicate to code that may be shared between multiple projects. Those flags are not used by core Dear ImGui)
1019  ImGuiConfigFlags_IsSRGB = 1 << 20, // Application is SRGB-aware.
1020  ImGuiConfigFlags_IsTouchScreen = 1 << 21 // Application is using a touch screen instead of a mouse.
1021 };

1199 // Enumateration for ImGui::SetWindow***(), SetNextWindow***(), SetNextItem***() functions
1200 // Represent a condition.

1202 enum ImGuiCond_
1203 {

1210 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1211 // Helpers: Memory allocations macros
1212 // IM_MALLOC(), IM_FREE(), IM_NEW(), IM_PLACEMENT_NEW(), IM_DELETE()
1213 // We call C++ constructor on own allocated memory via the placement "new(ptr) Type()" syntax.
1214 // Defining a custom placement new() with a dummy parameter allows us to bypass including <new> which on some platforms complains when user has disabled exceptions.
1215 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1216 
1217 struct ImNewDummy {};
1218 inline void* operator new(size_t, ImNewDummy, void* ptr) { return ptr; }
1219 inline void operator delete(void*, ImNewDummy, void*) {} // This is only required so we can use the symmetrical new()
1220 #define IM_ALLOC(_SIZE) ImGui::MemAlloc(_SIZE)
1221 #define IM_FREE(_PTR) ImGui::MemFree(_PTR)
1222 #define IM_PLACEMENT_NEW(_PTR) new(ImNewDummy(), _PTR)
1223 #define IM_NEW(_TYPE) new(ImNewDummy(), ImGui::MemAlloc(sizeof(_TYPE))) _TYPE
1224 template<typename T> void IM_DELETE(T* p) { if (p) { p->~T(); ImGui::MemFree(p); } }
1225 
1226 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1227 // Helper: ImVector<>
1228 // Lightweight std::vector<>-like class to avoid dragging dependencies (also, some implementations of STL with debug enabled are absurdly slow, we bypass it so our code runs fast in debug).
1229 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1230 // - You generally do NOT need to care or use this ever. But we need to make it available in imgui.h because some of our public structures are relying on it.
1231 // - We use std-like naming convention here, which is a little unusual for this codebase.
1232 // - Important: clear() frees memory, resize(0) keep the allocated buffer. We use resize(0) a lot to intentionally recycle allocated buffers across frames and amortize our costs.
1233 // - Important: our implementation does NOT call C++ constructors/destructors, we treat everything as raw data! This is intentional but be extra mindful of that,
1234 // Do NOT use this class as a std::vector replacement in your own code! Many of the structures used by dear imgui can be safely initialized by a zero-memset.
1235 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1236 
1237 template<typename T>
1238 struct ImVector
1239 {
1240  int Size;
1241  int Capacity;
1242  T* Data;
1243 
1244  // Provide standard typedefs but we don't use them ourselves.
1245  typedef T value_type;
1246  typedef value_type* iterator;
1247  typedef const value_type* const_iterator;
1248 
1249  // Constructors, destructor
1250  inline ImVector() { Size = Capacity = 0; Data = NULL; }
1251  inline ImVector(const ImVector<T>& src) { Size = Capacity = 0; Data = NULL; operator=(src); }
1252  inline ImVector<T>& operator=(const ImVector<T>& src) { clear(); resize(src.Size); memcpy(Data, src.Data, (size_t)Size * sizeof(T)); return *this; }
1253  inline ~ImVector() { if (Data) IM_FREE(Data); }
1254 
1255  inline bool empty() const { return Size == 0; }
1256  inline int size() const { return Size; }
1257  inline int size_in_bytes() const { return Size * (int)sizeof(T); }
1258  inline int capacity() const { return Capacity; }
1259  inline T& operator[](int i) { IM_ASSERT(i < Size); return Data[i]; }
1260  inline const T& operator[](int i) const { IM_ASSERT(i < Size); return Data[i]; }
1261 
1262  inline void clear() { if (Data) { Size = Capacity = 0; IM_FREE(Data); Data = NULL; } }
1263  inline T* begin() { return Data; }
1264  inline const T* begin() const { return Data; }
1265  inline T* end() { return Data + Size; }
1266  inline const T* end() const { return Data + Size; }
1267  inline T& front() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[0]; }
1268  inline const T& front() const { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[0]; }
1269  inline T& back() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[Size - 1]; }
1270  inline const T& back() const { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[Size - 1]; }
1271  inline void swap(ImVector<T>& rhs) { int rhs_size = rhs.Size; rhs.Size = Size; Size = rhs_size; int rhs_cap = rhs.Capacity; rhs.Capacity = Capacity; Capacity = rhs_cap; T* rhs_data = rhs.Data; rhs.Data = Data; Data = rhs_data; }
1272 
1273  inline int _grow_capacity(int sz) const { int new_capacity = Capacity ? (Capacity + Capacity/2) : 8; return new_capacity > sz ? new_capacity : sz; }
1274  inline void resize(int new_size) { if (new_size > Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(new_size)); Size = new_size; }
1275  inline void resize(int new_size, const T& v) { if (new_size > Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(new_size)); if (new_size > Size) for (int n = Size; n < new_size; n++) memcpy(&Data[n], &v, sizeof(v)); Size = new_size; }
1276  inline void shrink(int new_size) { IM_ASSERT(new_size <= Size); Size = new_size; }
1277  inline void reserve(int new_capacity) { if (new_capacity <= Capacity) return; T* new_data = (T*)IM_ALLOC((size_t)new_capacity * sizeof(T)); if (Data) { memcpy(new_data, Data, (size_t)Size * sizeof(T)); IM_FREE(Data); } Data = new_data; Capacity = new_capacity; }
1278 
1279  // NB: It is illegal to call push_back/push_front/insert with a reference pointing inside the ImVector data itself! e.g. v.push_back(v[10]) is forbidden.
1280  inline void push_back(const T& v) { if (Size == Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(Size + 1)); memcpy(&Data[Size], &v, sizeof(v)); Size++; }
1281  inline void pop_back() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); Size--; }
1282  inline void push_front(const T& v) { if (Size == 0) push_back(v); else insert(Data, v); }
1283  inline T* erase(const T* it) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data+Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; memmove(Data + off, Data + off + 1, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off - 1) * sizeof(T)); Size--; return Data + off; }
1284  inline T* erase(const T* it, const T* it_last){ IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data+Size && it_last > it && it_last <= Data+Size); const ptrdiff_t count = it_last - it; const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; memmove(Data + off, Data + off + count, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off - count) * sizeof(T)); Size -= (int)count; return Data + off; }
1285  inline T* erase_unsorted(const T* it) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data+Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; if (it < Data+Size-1) memcpy(Data + off, Data + Size - 1, sizeof(T)); Size--; return Data + off; }
1286  inline T* insert(const T* it, const T& v) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it <= Data+Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; if (Size == Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(Size + 1)); if (off < (int)Size) memmove(Data + off + 1, Data + off, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off) * sizeof(T)); memcpy(&Data[off], &v, sizeof(v)); Size++; return Data + off; }
1287  inline bool contains(const T& v) const { const T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data++ == v) return true; return false; }
1288  inline T* find(const T& v) { T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data == v) break; else ++data; return data; }
1289  inline const T* find(const T& v) const { const T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data == v) break; else ++data; return data; }
1290  inline bool find_erase(const T& v) { const T* it = find(v); if (it < Data + Size) { erase(it); return true; } return false; }
1291  inline bool find_erase_unsorted(const T& v) { const T* it = find(v); if (it < Data + Size) { erase_unsorted(it); return true; } return false; }
1292  inline int index_from_ptr(const T* it) const { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data + Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; return (int)off; }
1293 };

1331  ImVec2 SelectableTextAlign; // Alignment of selectable text when selectable is larger than text. Defaults to (0.0f, 0.0f) (top-left aligned).
1332  ImVec2 DisplayWindowPadding; // Window position are clamped to be visible within the display area by at least this amount. Only applies to regular windows.
1333  ImVec2 DisplaySafeAreaPadding; // If you cannot see the edges of your screen (e.g. on a TV) increase the safe area padding. Apply to popups/tooltips as well regular windows. NB: Prefer configuring your TV sets correctly!
1334  float MouseCursorScale; // Scale software rendered mouse cursor (when io.MouseDrawCursor is enabled). May be removed later.
1335  bool AntiAliasedLines; // Enable anti-aliasing on lines/borders. Disable if you are really tight on CPU/GPU.
1336  bool AntiAliasedFill; // Enable anti-aliasing on filled shapes (rounded rectangles, circles, etc.)
1337  float CurveTessellationTol; // Tessellation tolerance when using PathBezierCurveTo() without a specific number of segments. Decrease for highly tessellated curves (higher quality, more polygons), increase to reduce quality.

1485 // Shared state of InputText(), passed as an argument to your callback when a ImGuiInputTextFlags_Callback* flag is used.
1486 // The callback function should return 0 by default.
1487 // Callbacks (follow a flag name and see comments in ImGuiInputTextFlags_ declarations for more details)
1488 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackCompletion: Callback on pressing TAB
1489 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackHistory: Callback on pressing Up/Down arrows
1490 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackAlways: Callback on each iteration
1491 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackCharFilter: Callback on character inputs to replace or discard them. Modify 'EventChar' to replace or discard, or return 1 in callback to discard.
1492 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackResize: Callback on buffer capacity changes request (beyond 'buf_size' parameter value), allowing the string to grow.
1493 struct ImGuiInputTextCallbackData
1494 {
1495  ImGuiInputTextFlags EventFlag; // One ImGuiInputTextFlags_Callback* // Read-only
1496  ImGuiInputTextFlags Flags; // What user passed to InputText() // Read-only
1497  void* UserData; // What user passed to InputText() // Read-only
1498 
1499  // Arguments for the different callback events
1500  // - To modify the text buffer in a callback, prefer using the InsertChars() / DeleteChars() function. InsertChars() will take care of calling the resize callback if necessary.
1501  // - If you know your edits are not going to resize the underlying buffer allocation, you may modify the contents of 'Buf[]' directly. You need to update 'BufTextLen' accordingly (0 <= BufTextLen < BufSize) and set 'BufDirty'' to true so InputText can update its internal state.
1502  ImWchar EventChar; // Character input // Read-write // [CharFilter] Replace character with another one, or set to zero to drop. return 1 is equivalent to setting EventChar=0;
1503  ImGuiKey EventKey; // Key pressed (Up/Down/TAB) // Read-only // [Completion,History]
1504  char* Buf; // Text buffer // Read-write // [Resize] Can replace pointer / [Completion,History,Always] Only write to pointed data, don't replace the actual pointer!
1505  int BufTextLen; // Text length (in bytes) // Read-write // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Exclude zero-terminator storage. In C land: == strlen(some_text), in C++ land: string.length()
1506  int BufSize; // Buffer size (in bytes) = capacity+1 // Read-only // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Include zero-terminator storage. In C land == ARRAYSIZE(my_char_array), in C++ land: string.capacity()+1
1507  bool BufDirty; // Set if you modify Buf/BufTextLen! // Write // [Completion,History,Always]
1508  int CursorPos; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always]
1509  int SelectionStart; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always] == to SelectionEnd when no selection)
1510  int SelectionEnd; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always]
1511 
1512  // Helper functions for text manipulation.
1513  // Use those function to benefit from the CallbackResize behaviors. Calling those function reset the selection.
1514  IMGUI_API ImGuiInputTextCallbackData();
1515  IMGUI_API void DeleteChars(int pos, int bytes_count);
1516  IMGUI_API void InsertChars(int pos, const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL);
1517  bool HasSelection() const { return SelectionStart != SelectionEnd; }
1518 };

1596 // Helper: Execute a block of code at maximum once a frame. Convenient if you want to quickly create an UI within deep-nested code that runs multiple times every frame.
1597 // Usage: static ImGuiOnceUponAFrame oaf; if (oaf) ImGui::Text("This will be called only once per frame");

1599 {
1600  ImGuiOnceUponAFrame() { RefFrame = -1; }

1652 // Helper: Key->Value storage
1653 // Typically you don't have to worry about this since a storage is held within each Window.
1654 // We use it to e.g. store collapse state for a tree (Int 0/1)
1655 // This is optimized for efficient lookup (dichotomy into a contiguous buffer) and rare insertion (typically tied to user interactions aka max once a frame)
1656 // You can use it as custom user storage for temporary values. Declare your own storage if, for example:
1657 // - You want to manipulate the open/close state of a particular sub-tree in your interface (tree node uses Int 0/1 to store their state).
1658 // - You want to store custom debug data easily without adding or editing structures in your code (probably not efficient, but convenient)
1659 // Types are NOT stored, so it is up to you to make sure your Key don't collide with different types.
1660 struct ImGuiStorage
1661 {
1662  // [Internal]
1663  struct ImGuiStoragePair
1664  {
1665  ImGuiID key;
1666  union { int val_i; float val_f; void* val_p; };
1667  ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, int _val_i) { key = _key; val_i = _val_i; }
1668  ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, float _val_f) { key = _key; val_f = _val_f; }
1669  ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, void* _val_p) { key = _key; val_p = _val_p; }
1670  };
1671 
1672  ImVector<ImGuiStoragePair> Data;
1673 
1674  // - Get***() functions find pair, never add/allocate. Pairs are sorted so a query is O(log N)
1675  // - Set***() functions find pair, insertion on demand if missing.
1676  // - Sorted insertion is costly, paid once. A typical frame shouldn't need to insert any new pair.
1677  void Clear() { Data.clear(); }
1678  IMGUI_API int GetInt(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0) const;
1679  IMGUI_API void SetInt(ImGuiID key, int val);
1680  IMGUI_API bool GetBool(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false) const;
1681  IMGUI_API void SetBool(ImGuiID key, bool val);
1682  IMGUI_API float GetFloat(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f) const;
1683  IMGUI_API void SetFloat(ImGuiID key, float val);
1684  IMGUI_API void* GetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key) const; // default_val is NULL
1685  IMGUI_API void SetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key, void* val);
1686 
1687  // - Get***Ref() functions finds pair, insert on demand if missing, return pointer. Useful if you intend to do Get+Set.
1688  // - References are only valid until a new value is added to the storage. Calling a Set***() function or a Get***Ref() function invalidates the pointer.
1689  // - A typical use case where this is convenient for quick hacking (e.g. add storage during a live Edit&Continue session if you can't modify existing struct)
1690  // float* pvar = ImGui::GetFloatRef(key); ImGui::SliderFloat("var", pvar, 0, 100.0f); some_var += *pvar;
1691  IMGUI_API int* GetIntRef(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0);
1692  IMGUI_API bool* GetBoolRef(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false);
1693  IMGUI_API float* GetFloatRef(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f);
1694  IMGUI_API void** GetVoidPtrRef(ImGuiID key, void* default_val = NULL);
1695 
1696  // Use on your own storage if you know only integer are being stored (open/close all tree nodes)
1697  IMGUI_API void SetAllInt(int val);
1698 
1699  // For quicker full rebuild of a storage (instead of an incremental one), you may add all your contents and then sort once.
1700  IMGUI_API void BuildSortByKey();
1701 };

1703 // Helper: Manually clip large list of items.
1704 // If you are submitting lots of evenly spaced items and you have a random access to the list, you can perform coarse clipping based on visibility to save yourself from processing those items at all.
1705 // The clipper calculates the range of visible items and advance the cursor to compensate for the non-visible items we have skipped.
1706 // ImGui already clip items based on their bounds but it needs to measure text size to do so. Coarse clipping before submission makes this cost and your own data fetching/submission cost null.
1707 // Usage:
1708 // ImGuiListClipper clipper(1000); // we have 1000 elements, evenly spaced.
1709 // while (clipper.Step())
1710 // for (int i = clipper.DisplayStart; i < clipper.DisplayEnd; i++)
1711 // ImGui::Text("line number %d", i);
1712 // - Step 0: the clipper let you process the first element, regardless of it being visible or not, so we can measure the element height (step skipped if we passed a known height as second arg to constructor).
1713 // - Step 1: the clipper infer height from first element, calculate the actual range of elements to display, and position the cursor before the first element.
1714 // - (Step 2: dummy step only required if an explicit items_height was passed to constructor or Begin() and user call Step(). Does nothing and switch to Step 3.)
1715 // - Step 3: the clipper validate that we have reached the expected Y position (corresponding to element DisplayEnd), advance the cursor to the end of the list and then returns 'false' to end the loop.
1716 struct ImGuiListClipper
1717 {
1718  float StartPosY;
1719  float ItemsHeight;
1720  int ItemsCount, StepNo, DisplayStart, DisplayEnd;
1721 
1722  // items_count: Use -1 to ignore (you can call Begin later). Use INT_MAX if you don't know how many items you have (in which case the cursor won't be advanced in the final step).
1723  // items_height: Use -1.0f to be calculated automatically on first step. Otherwise pass in the distance between your items, typically GetTextLineHeightWithSpacing() or GetFrameHeightWithSpacing().
1724  // If you don't specify an items_height, you NEED to call Step(). If you specify items_height you may call the old Begin()/End() api directly, but prefer calling Step().
1725  ImGuiListClipper(int items_count = -1, float items_height = -1.0f) { Begin(items_count, items_height); } // NB: Begin() initialize every fields (as we allow user to call Begin/End multiple times on a same instance if they want).
1726  ~ImGuiListClipper() { IM_ASSERT(ItemsCount == -1); } // Assert if user forgot to call End() or Step() until false.
1727 
1728  IMGUI_API bool Step(); // Call until it returns false. The DisplayStart/DisplayEnd fields will be set and you can process/draw those items.
1729  IMGUI_API void Begin(int items_count, float items_height = -1.0f); // Automatically called by constructor if you passed 'items_count' or by Step() in Step 1.
1730  IMGUI_API void End(); // Automatically called on the last call of Step() that returns false.
1731 };

1733 // Helpers macros to generate 32-bit encoded colors
1734 #ifdef IMGUI_USE_BGRA_PACKED_COLOR
1735 #define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 16
1736 #define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8
1737 #define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 0
1738 #define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24
1739 #define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000
1740 #else
1741 #define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 0
1742 #define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8
1743 #define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 16
1744 #define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24
1745 #define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000
1746 #endif
1747 #define IM_COL32(R,G,B,A) (((ImU32)(A)<<IM_COL32_A_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(B)<<IM_COL32_B_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(G)<<IM_COL32_G_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(R)<<IM_COL32_R_SHIFT))
1748 #define IM_COL32_WHITE IM_COL32(255,255,255,255) // Opaque white = 0xFFFFFFFF
1749 #define IM_COL32_BLACK IM_COL32(0,0,0,255) // Opaque black
1750 #define IM_COL32_BLACK_TRANS IM_COL32(0,0,0,0) // Transparent black = 0x00000000
1751 
1752 // Helper: ImColor() implicitly converts colors to either ImU32 (packed 4x1 byte) or ImVec4 (4x1 float)
1753 // Prefer using IM_COL32() macros if you want a guaranteed compile-time ImU32 for usage with ImDrawList API.
1754 // **Avoid storing ImColor! Store either u32 of ImVec4. This is not a full-featured color class. MAY OBSOLETE.
1755 // **None of the ImGui API are using ImColor directly but you can use it as a convenience to pass colors in either ImU32 or ImVec4 formats. Explicitly cast to ImU32 or ImVec4 if needed.
1756 struct ImColor
1757 {
1758  ImVec4 Value;
1759 
1760  ImColor() { Value.x = Value.y = Value.z = Value.w = 0.0f; }
1761  ImColor(int r, int g, int b, int a = 255) { float sc = 1.0f/255.0f; Value.x = (float)r * sc; Value.y = (float)g * sc; Value.z = (float)b * sc; Value.w = (float)a * sc; }
1762  ImColor(ImU32 rgba) { float sc = 1.0f/255.0f; Value.x = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_R_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; Value.y = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_G_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; Value.z = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_B_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; Value.w = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_A_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; }
1763  ImColor(float r, float g, float b, float a = 1.0f) { Value.x = r; Value.y = g; Value.z = b; Value.w = a; }
1764  ImColor(const ImVec4& col) { Value = col; }
1765  inline operator ImU32() const { return ImGui::ColorConvertFloat4ToU32(Value); }
1766  inline operator ImVec4() const { return Value; }
1767 
1768  // FIXME-OBSOLETE: May need to obsolete/cleanup those helpers.
1769  inline void SetHSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f){ ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, Value.x, Value.y, Value.z); Value.w = a; }
1770  static ImColor HSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f) { float r,g,b; ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, r, g, b); return ImColor(r,g,b,a); }
1771 };
1772 
1773 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1774 // Draw List API (ImDrawCmd, ImDrawIdx, ImDrawVert, ImDrawChannel, ImDrawListSplitter, ImDrawListFlags, ImDrawList, ImDrawData)
1775 // Hold a series of drawing commands. The user provides a renderer for ImDrawData which essentially contains an array of ImDrawList.
1776 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1777 
1778 // Draw callbacks for advanced uses.
1779 // NB: You most likely do NOT need to use draw callbacks just to create your own widget or customized UI rendering,
1780 // you can poke into the draw list for that! Draw callback may be useful for example to:
1781 // A) Change your GPU render state,
1782 // B) render a complex 3D scene inside a UI element without an intermediate texture/render target, etc.
1783 // The expected behavior from your rendering function is 'if (cmd.UserCallback != NULL) { cmd.UserCallback(parent_list, cmd); } else { RenderTriangles() }'
1784 // If you want to override the signature of ImDrawCallback, you can simply use e.g. '#define ImDrawCallback MyDrawCallback' (in imconfig.h) + update rendering back-end accordingly.
1785 #ifndef ImDrawCallback
1786 typedef void (*ImDrawCallback)(const ImDrawList* parent_list, const ImDrawCmd* cmd);
1787 #endif
1788 
1789 // Special Draw callback value to request renderer back-end to reset the graphics/render state.
1790 // The renderer back-end needs to handle this special value, otherwise it will crash trying to call a function at this address.
1791 // This is useful for example if you submitted callbacks which you know have altered the render state and you want it to be restored.
1792 // It is not done by default because they are many perfectly useful way of altering render state for imgui contents (e.g. changing shader/blending settings before an Image call).
1793 #define ImDrawCallback_ResetRenderState (ImDrawCallback)(-1)
1794 
1795 // Typically, 1 command = 1 GPU draw call (unless command is a callback)
1796 // Pre 1.71 back-ends will typically ignore the VtxOffset/IdxOffset fields. When 'io.BackendFlags & ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset'
1797 // is enabled, those fields allow us to render meshes larger than 64K vertices while keeping 16-bit indices.
1798 struct ImDrawCmd
1799 {
1800  unsigned int ElemCount; // Number of indices (multiple of 3) to be rendered as triangles. Vertices are stored in the callee ImDrawList's vtx_buffer[] array, indices in idx_buffer[].
1801  ImVec4 ClipRect; // Clipping rectangle (x1, y1, x2, y2). Subtract ImDrawData->DisplayPos to get clipping rectangle in "viewport" coordinates
1802  ImTextureID TextureId; // User-provided texture ID. Set by user in ImfontAtlas::SetTexID() for fonts or passed to Image*() functions. Ignore if never using images or multiple fonts atlas.
1803  unsigned int VtxOffset; // Start offset in vertex buffer. Pre-1.71 or without ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset: always 0. With ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset: may be >0 to support meshes larger than 64K vertices with 16-bit indices.
1804  unsigned int IdxOffset; // Start offset in index buffer. Always equal to sum of ElemCount drawn so far.
1805  ImDrawCallback UserCallback; // If != NULL, call the function instead of rendering the vertices. clip_rect and texture_id will be set normally.
1806  void* UserCallbackData; // The draw callback code can access this.
1807 
1808  ImDrawCmd() { ElemCount = 0; TextureId = (ImTextureID)NULL; VtxOffset = IdxOffset = 0; UserCallback = NULL; UserCallbackData = NULL; }
1809 };
1810 
1811 // Vertex index
1812 // (to allow large meshes with 16-bit indices: set 'io.BackendFlags |= ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset' and handle ImDrawCmd::VtxOffset in the renderer back-end)
1813 // (to use 32-bit indices: override with '#define ImDrawIdx unsigned int' in imconfig.h)
1814 #ifndef ImDrawIdx
1815 typedef unsigned short ImDrawIdx;
1816 #endif
1817 
1818 // Vertex layout
1819 #ifndef IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT
1820 struct ImDrawVert
1821 {
1822  ImVec2 pos;
1823  ImVec2 uv;
1824  ImU32 col;
1825 };
1826 #else
1827 // You can override the vertex format layout by defining IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT in imconfig.h
1828 // The code expect ImVec2 pos (8 bytes), ImVec2 uv (8 bytes), ImU32 col (4 bytes), but you can re-order them or add other fields as needed to simplify integration in your engine.
1829 // The type has to be described within the macro (you can either declare the struct or use a typedef). This is because ImVec2/ImU32 are likely not declared a the time you'd want to set your type up.
1830 // NOTE: IMGUI DOESN'T CLEAR THE STRUCTURE AND DOESN'T CALL A CONSTRUCTOR SO ANY CUSTOM FIELD WILL BE UNINITIALIZED. IF YOU ADD EXTRA FIELDS (SUCH AS A 'Z' COORDINATES) YOU WILL NEED TO CLEAR THEM DURING RENDER OR TO IGNORE THEM.
1831 IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT;
1832 #endif
1833 
1834 // For use by ImDrawListSplitter.
1835 struct ImDrawChannel
1836 {
1837  ImVector<ImDrawCmd> _CmdBuffer;
1838  ImVector<ImDrawIdx> _IdxBuffer;
1839 };
1840 
1841 // Split/Merge functions are used to split the draw list into different layers which can be drawn into out of order.
1842 // This is used by the Columns api, so items of each column can be batched together in a same draw call.
1843 struct ImDrawListSplitter
1844 {
1845  int _Current; // Current channel number (0)
1846  int _Count; // Number of active channels (1+)
1847  ImVector<ImDrawChannel> _Channels; // Draw channels (not resized down so _Count might be < Channels.Size)
1848 
1849  inline ImDrawListSplitter() { Clear(); }
1850  inline ~ImDrawListSplitter() { ClearFreeMemory(); }
1851  inline void Clear() { _Current = 0; _Count = 1; } // Do not clear Channels[] so our allocations are reused next frame
1852  IMGUI_API void ClearFreeMemory();
1853  IMGUI_API void Split(ImDrawList* draw_list, int count);
1854  IMGUI_API void Merge(ImDrawList* draw_list);
1855  IMGUI_API void SetCurrentChannel(ImDrawList* draw_list, int channel_idx);
1856 };
1857 
1858 enum ImDrawCornerFlags_
1859 {
1860  ImDrawCornerFlags_None = 0,
1861  ImDrawCornerFlags_TopLeft = 1 << 0, // 0x1
1862  ImDrawCornerFlags_TopRight = 1 << 1, // 0x2
1863  ImDrawCornerFlags_BotLeft = 1 << 2, // 0x4
1864  ImDrawCornerFlags_BotRight = 1 << 3, // 0x8
1865  ImDrawCornerFlags_Top = ImDrawCornerFlags_TopLeft | ImDrawCornerFlags_TopRight, // 0x3
1866  ImDrawCornerFlags_Bot = ImDrawCornerFlags_BotLeft | ImDrawCornerFlags_BotRight, // 0xC
1867  ImDrawCornerFlags_Left = ImDrawCornerFlags_TopLeft | ImDrawCornerFlags_BotLeft, // 0x5
1868  ImDrawCornerFlags_Right = ImDrawCornerFlags_TopRight | ImDrawCornerFlags_BotRight, // 0xA
1869  ImDrawCornerFlags_All = 0xF // In your function calls you may use ~0 (= all bits sets) instead of ImDrawCornerFlags_All, as a convenience
1870 };
1871 
1872 enum ImDrawListFlags_
1873 {
1874  ImDrawListFlags_None = 0,
1875  ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedLines = 1 << 0, // Lines are anti-aliased (*2 the number of triangles for 1.0f wide line, otherwise *3 the number of triangles)
1876  ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedFill = 1 << 1, // Filled shapes have anti-aliased edges (*2 the number of vertices)
1877  ImDrawListFlags_AllowVtxOffset = 1 << 2 // Can emit 'VtxOffset > 0' to allow large meshes. Set when 'ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset' is enabled.
1878 };
1879 
1880 // Draw command list
1881 // This is the low-level list of polygons that ImGui:: functions are filling. At the end of the frame,
1882 // all command lists are passed to your ImGuiIO::RenderDrawListFn function for rendering.
1883 // Each dear imgui window contains its own ImDrawList. You can use ImGui::GetWindowDrawList() to
1884 // access the current window draw list and draw custom primitives.
1885 // You can interleave normal ImGui:: calls and adding primitives to the current draw list.
1886 // All positions are generally in pixel coordinates (top-left at (0,0), bottom-right at io.DisplaySize), but you are totally free to apply whatever transformation matrix to want to the data (if you apply such transformation you'll want to apply it to ClipRect as well)
1887 // Important: Primitives are always added to the list and not culled (culling is done at higher-level by ImGui:: functions), if you use this API a lot consider coarse culling your drawn objects.
1888 struct ImDrawList
1889 {
1890  // This is what you have to render
1891  ImVector<ImDrawCmd> CmdBuffer; // Draw commands. Typically 1 command = 1 GPU draw call, unless the command is a callback.
1892  ImVector<ImDrawIdx> IdxBuffer; // Index buffer. Each command consume ImDrawCmd::ElemCount of those
1893  ImVector<ImDrawVert> VtxBuffer; // Vertex buffer.
1894  ImDrawListFlags Flags; // Flags, you may poke into these to adjust anti-aliasing settings per-primitive.
1895 
1896  // [Internal, used while building lists]
1897  const ImDrawListSharedData* _Data; // Pointer to shared draw data (you can use ImGui::GetDrawListSharedData() to get the one from current ImGui context)
1898  const char* _OwnerName; // Pointer to owner window's name for debugging
1899  unsigned int _VtxCurrentOffset; // [Internal] Always 0 unless 'Flags & ImDrawListFlags_AllowVtxOffset'.
1900  unsigned int _VtxCurrentIdx; // [Internal] Generally == VtxBuffer.Size unless we are past 64K vertices, in which case this gets reset to 0.
1901  ImDrawVert* _VtxWritePtr; // [Internal] point within VtxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
1902  ImDrawIdx* _IdxWritePtr; // [Internal] point within IdxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
1903  ImVector<ImVec4> _ClipRectStack; // [Internal]
1904  ImVector<ImTextureID> _TextureIdStack; // [Internal]
1905  ImVector<ImVec2> _Path; // [Internal] current path building
1906  ImDrawListSplitter _Splitter; // [Internal] for channels api
1907 
1908  // If you want to create ImDrawList instances, pass them ImGui::GetDrawListSharedData() or create and use your own ImDrawListSharedData (so you can use ImDrawList without ImGui)
1909  ImDrawList(const ImDrawListSharedData* shared_data) { _Data = shared_data; _OwnerName = NULL; Clear(); }
1910  ~ImDrawList() { ClearFreeMemory(); }
1911  IMGUI_API void PushClipRect(ImVec2 clip_rect_min, ImVec2 clip_rect_max, bool intersect_with_current_clip_rect = false); // Render-level scissoring. This is passed down to your render function but not used for CPU-side coarse clipping. Prefer using higher-level ImGui::PushClipRect() to affect logic (hit-testing and widget culling)
1912  IMGUI_API void PushClipRectFullScreen();
1913  IMGUI_API void PopClipRect();
1914  IMGUI_API void PushTextureID(ImTextureID texture_id);
1915  IMGUI_API void PopTextureID();
1916  inline ImVec2 GetClipRectMin() const { const ImVec4& cr = _ClipRectStack.back(); return ImVec2(cr.x, cr.y); }
1917  inline ImVec2 GetClipRectMax() const { const ImVec4& cr = _ClipRectStack.back(); return ImVec2(cr.z, cr.w); }
1918 
1919  // Primitives
1920  // - For rectangular primitives, "p_min" and "p_max" represent the upper-left and lower-right corners.
1921  IMGUI_API void AddLine(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, ImU32 col, float thickness = 1.0f);
1922  IMGUI_API void AddRect(const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, ImU32 col, float rounding = 0.0f, ImDrawCornerFlags rounding_corners = ImDrawCornerFlags_All, float thickness = 1.0f); // a: upper-left, b: lower-right (== upper-left + size), rounding_corners_flags: 4 bits corresponding to which corner to round
1923  IMGUI_API void AddRectFilled(const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, ImU32 col, float rounding = 0.0f, ImDrawCornerFlags rounding_corners = ImDrawCornerFlags_All); // a: upper-left, b: lower-right (== upper-left + size)
1924  IMGUI_API void AddRectFilledMultiColor(const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, ImU32 col_upr_left, ImU32 col_upr_right, ImU32 col_bot_right, ImU32 col_bot_left);
1925  IMGUI_API void AddQuad(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, ImU32 col, float thickness = 1.0f);
1926  IMGUI_API void AddQuadFilled(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, ImU32 col);
1927  IMGUI_API void AddTriangle(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, ImU32 col, float thickness = 1.0f);
1928  IMGUI_API void AddTriangleFilled(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, ImU32 col);
1929  IMGUI_API void AddCircle(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments = 12, float thickness = 1.0f);
1930  IMGUI_API void AddCircleFilled(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments = 12);
1931  IMGUI_API void AddText(const ImVec2& pos, ImU32 col, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end = NULL);
1932  IMGUI_API void AddText(const ImFont* font, float font_size, const ImVec2& pos, ImU32 col, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end = NULL, float wrap_width = 0.0f, const ImVec4* cpu_fine_clip_rect = NULL);
1933  IMGUI_API void AddPolyline(const ImVec2* points, int num_points, ImU32 col, bool closed, float thickness);
1934  IMGUI_API void AddConvexPolyFilled(const ImVec2* points, int num_points, ImU32 col); // Note: Anti-aliased filling requires points to be in clockwise order.
1935  IMGUI_API void AddBezierCurve(const ImVec2& pos0, const ImVec2& cp0, const ImVec2& cp1, const ImVec2& pos1, ImU32 col, float thickness, int num_segments = 0);

1937  // Image primitives
1938  // - Read FAQ to understand what ImTextureID is.
1939  // - "p_min" and "p_max" represent the upper-left and lower-right corners of the rectangle.
1940  // - "uv_min" and "uv_max" represent the normalized texture coordinates to use for those corners. Using (0,0)->(1,1) texture coordinates will generally display the entire texture.
1941  IMGUI_API void AddImage(ImTextureID user_texture_id, const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, const ImVec2& uv_min = ImVec2(0, 0), const ImVec2& uv_max = ImVec2(1, 1), ImU32 col = IM_COL32_WHITE);
1942  IMGUI_API void AddImageQuad(ImTextureID user_texture_id, const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, const ImVec2& uv1 = ImVec2(0, 0), const ImVec2& uv2 = ImVec2(1, 0), const ImVec2& uv3 = ImVec2(1, 1), const ImVec2& uv4 = ImVec2(0, 1), ImU32 col = IM_COL32_WHITE);
1943  IMGUI_API void AddImageRounded(ImTextureID user_texture_id, const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, const ImVec2& uv_min, const ImVec2& uv_max, ImU32 col, float rounding, ImDrawCornerFlags rounding_corners = ImDrawCornerFlags_All);
1944 
1945  // Stateful path API, add points then finish with PathFillConvex() or PathStroke()
1946  inline void PathClear() { _Path.Size = 0; }
1947  inline void PathLineTo(const ImVec2& pos) { _Path.push_back(pos); }
1948  inline void PathLineToMergeDuplicate(const ImVec2& pos) { if (_Path.Size == 0 || memcmp(&_Path.Data[_Path.Size-1], &pos, 8) != 0) _Path.push_back(pos); }
1949  inline void PathFillConvex(ImU32 col) { AddConvexPolyFilled(_Path.Data, _Path.Size, col); _Path.Size = 0; } // Note: Anti-aliased filling requires points to be in clockwise order.
1950  inline void PathStroke(ImU32 col, bool closed, float thickness = 1.0f) { AddPolyline(_Path.Data, _Path.Size, col, closed, thickness); _Path.Size = 0; }
1951  IMGUI_API void PathArcTo(const ImVec2& center, float radius, float a_min, float a_max, int num_segments = 10);
1952  IMGUI_API void PathArcToFast(const ImVec2& center, float radius, int a_min_of_12, int a_max_of_12); // Use precomputed angles for a 12 steps circle
1953  IMGUI_API void PathBezierCurveTo(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, int num_segments = 0);

1958  IMGUI_API void AddDrawCmd(); // This is useful if you need to forcefully create a new draw call (to allow for dependent rendering / blending). Otherwise primitives are merged into the same draw-call as much as possible
1959  IMGUI_API ImDrawList* CloneOutput() const; // Create a clone of the CmdBuffer/IdxBuffer/VtxBuffer.

1961  // Advanced: Channels
1962  // - Use to split render into layers. By switching channels to can render out-of-order (e.g. submit foreground primitives before background primitives)
1963  // - Use to minimize draw calls (e.g. if going back-and-forth between multiple non-overlapping clipping rectangles, prefer to append into separate channels then merge at the end)
1964  inline void ChannelsSplit(int count) { _Splitter.Split(this, count); }
1965  inline void ChannelsMerge() { _Splitter.Merge(this); }

1976  inline void PrimWriteVtx(const ImVec2& pos, const ImVec2& uv, ImU32 col){ _VtxWritePtr->pos = pos; _VtxWritePtr->uv = uv; _VtxWritePtr->col = col; _VtxWritePtr++; _VtxCurrentIdx++; }
1977  inline void PrimWriteIdx(ImDrawIdx idx) { *_IdxWritePtr = idx; _IdxWritePtr++; }
1978  inline void PrimVtx(const ImVec2& pos, const ImVec2& uv, ImU32 col) { PrimWriteIdx((ImDrawIdx)_VtxCurrentIdx); PrimWriteVtx(pos, uv, col); }

1983 // All draw data to render a Dear ImGui frame
1984 // (NB: the style and the naming convention here is a little inconsistent, we currently preserve them for backward compatibility purpose,
1985 // as this is one of the oldest structure exposed by the library! Basically, ImDrawList == CmdList)
1986 struct ImDrawData
1987 {
1988  bool Valid; // Only valid after Render() is called and before the next NewFrame() is called.
1989  ImDrawList** CmdLists; // Array of ImDrawList* to render. The ImDrawList are owned by ImGuiContext and only pointed to from here.
1990  int CmdListsCount; // Number of ImDrawList* to render
1991  int TotalIdxCount; // For convenience, sum of all ImDrawList's IdxBuffer.Size
1992  int TotalVtxCount; // For convenience, sum of all ImDrawList's VtxBuffer.Size
1993  ImVec2 DisplayPos; // Upper-left position of the viewport to render (== upper-left of the orthogonal projection matrix to use)
1994  ImVec2 DisplaySize; // Size of the viewport to render (== io.DisplaySize for the main viewport) (DisplayPos + DisplaySize == lower-right of the orthogonal projection matrix to use)
1995  ImVec2 FramebufferScale; // Amount of pixels for each unit of DisplaySize. Based on io.DisplayFramebufferScale. Generally (1,1) on normal display, (2,2) on OSX with Retina display.
1996 
1997  // Functions
1998  ImDrawData() { Valid = false; Clear(); }
1999  ~ImDrawData() { Clear(); }
2000  void Clear() { Valid = false; CmdLists = NULL; CmdListsCount = TotalVtxCount = TotalIdxCount = 0; DisplayPos = DisplaySize = FramebufferScale = ImVec2(0.f, 0.f); } // The ImDrawList are owned by ImGuiContext!
2001  IMGUI_API void DeIndexAllBuffers(); // Helper to convert all buffers from indexed to non-indexed, in case you cannot render indexed. Note: this is slow and most likely a waste of resources. Always prefer indexed rendering!
2002  IMGUI_API void ScaleClipRects(const ImVec2& fb_scale); // Helper to scale the ClipRect field of each ImDrawCmd. Use if your final output buffer is at a different scale than Dear ImGui expects, or if there is a difference between your window resolution and framebuffer resolution.
2003 };

2006 // Font API (ImFontConfig, ImFontGlyph, ImFontAtlasFlags, ImFontAtlas, ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder, ImFont)
2007 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2008 
2009 struct ImFontConfig
2010 {
2011  void* FontData; // // TTF/OTF data
2012  int FontDataSize; // // TTF/OTF data size
2013  bool FontDataOwnedByAtlas; // true // TTF/OTF data ownership taken by the container ImFontAtlas (will delete memory itself).
2014  int FontNo; // 0 // Index of font within TTF/OTF file
2015  float SizePixels; // // Size in pixels for rasterizer (more or less maps to the resulting font height).
2016  int OversampleH; // 3 // Rasterize at higher quality for sub-pixel positioning. Read https://github.com/nothings/stb/blob/master/tests/oversample/README.md for details.
2017  int OversampleV; // 1 // Rasterize at higher quality for sub-pixel positioning. We don't use sub-pixel positions on the Y axis.
2018  bool PixelSnapH; // false // Align every glyph to pixel boundary. Useful e.g. if you are merging a non-pixel aligned font with the default font. If enabled, you can set OversampleH/V to 1.
2019  ImVec2 GlyphExtraSpacing; // 0, 0 // Extra spacing (in pixels) between glyphs. Only X axis is supported for now.
2020  ImVec2 GlyphOffset; // 0, 0 // Offset all glyphs from this font input.
2021  const ImWchar* GlyphRanges; // NULL // Pointer to a user-provided list of Unicode range (2 value per range, values are inclusive, zero-terminated list). THE ARRAY DATA NEEDS TO PERSIST AS LONG AS THE FONT IS ALIVE.
2022  float GlyphMinAdvanceX; // 0 // Minimum AdvanceX for glyphs, set Min to align font icons, set both Min/Max to enforce mono-space font
2023  float GlyphMaxAdvanceX; // FLT_MAX // Maximum AdvanceX for glyphs
2024  bool MergeMode; // false // Merge into previous ImFont, so you can combine multiple inputs font into one ImFont (e.g. ASCII font + icons + Japanese glyphs). You may want to use GlyphOffset.y when merge font of different heights.
2025  unsigned int RasterizerFlags; // 0x00 // Settings for custom font rasterizer (e.g. ImGuiFreeType). Leave as zero if you aren't using one.
2026  float RasterizerMultiply; // 1.0f // Brighten (>1.0f) or darken (<1.0f) font output. Brightening small fonts may be a good workaround to make them more readable.
2027  ImWchar EllipsisChar; // -1 // Explicitly specify unicode codepoint of ellipsis character. When fonts are being merged first specified ellipsis will be used.
2028 
2029  // [Internal]
2030  char Name[40]; // Name (strictly to ease debugging)
2031  ImFont* DstFont;
2032 
2033  IMGUI_API ImFontConfig();
2034 };

2044 // Helper to build glyph ranges from text/string data. Feed your application strings/characters to it then call BuildRanges().
2045 // This is essentially a tightly packed of vector of 64k booleans = 8KB storage.
2046 struct ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder
2047 {
2048  ImVector<ImU32> UsedChars; // Store 1-bit per Unicode code point (0=unused, 1=used)
2049 
2050  ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder() { Clear(); }
2051  inline void Clear() { int size_in_bytes = (IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX+1) / 8; UsedChars.resize(size_in_bytes / (int)sizeof(ImU32)); memset(UsedChars.Data, 0, (size_t)size_in_bytes); }
2052  inline bool GetBit(int n) const { int off = (n >> 5); ImU32 mask = 1u << (n & 31); return (UsedChars[off] & mask) != 0; } // Get bit n in the array
2053  inline void SetBit(int n) { int off = (n >> 5); ImU32 mask = 1u << (n & 31); UsedChars[off] |= mask; } // Set bit n in the array
2054  inline void AddChar(ImWchar c) { SetBit(c); } // Add character
2055  IMGUI_API void AddText(const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL); // Add string (each character of the UTF-8 string are added)
2056  IMGUI_API void AddRanges(const ImWchar* ranges); // Add ranges, e.g. builder.AddRanges(ImFontAtlas::GetGlyphRangesDefault()) to force add all of ASCII/Latin+Ext
2057  IMGUI_API void BuildRanges(ImVector<ImWchar>* out_ranges); // Output new ranges
2058 };

2060 // See ImFontAtlas::AddCustomRectXXX functions.
2061 struct ImFontAtlasCustomRect
2062 {
2063  unsigned int ID; // Input // User ID. Use < 0x110000 to map into a font glyph, >= 0x110000 for other/internal/custom texture data.
2064  unsigned short Width, Height; // Input // Desired rectangle dimension
2065  unsigned short X, Y; // Output // Packed position in Atlas
2066  float GlyphAdvanceX; // Input // For custom font glyphs only (ID < 0x110000): glyph xadvance
2067  ImVec2 GlyphOffset; // Input // For custom font glyphs only (ID < 0x110000): glyph display offset
2068  ImFont* Font; // Input // For custom font glyphs only (ID < 0x110000): target font
2069  ImFontAtlasCustomRect() { ID = 0xFFFFFFFF; Width = Height = 0; X = Y = 0xFFFF; GlyphAdvanceX = 0.0f; GlyphOffset = ImVec2(0,0); Font = NULL; }
2070  bool IsPacked() const { return X != 0xFFFF; }
2071 };
